form.steps:
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight plate in front of your thighs with your palms facing your body. 
2. Keeping your back straight and core engaged, lift the plate forward and upward, maintaining a slight bend in your elbows, until your arms are parallel to the floor. 
3. Hold this position for the desired amount of time, keeping your shoulders down and back.

form.Elbows: Maintain a slight bend in your elbows throughout the exercise.
form.Shoulders: Keep your shoulders down and back, avoiding shrugging them up towards your ears.
form.Back: Keep your back straight, avoiding any arching or rounding.
form.Core: Engage your core muscles to maintain stability and proper posture.
form.Grip: Hold the plate with a secure grip, ensuring it doesn't slip.

commonMistakes.Using Momentum: Swinging the weight up instead of using a controlled movement.
commonMistakes.Shrugging Shoulders: Raising your shoulders towards your ears, which can lead to neck strain.
commonMistakes.Arching Back: Overarching your lower back, which can cause pain and injury.
commonMistakes.Holding Breath: Remember to breathe throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes.Using Excessive Weight: Choosing a weight that is too heavy, leading to improper form and potential injury.

comments.Muscle Activation: The front hold primarily targets the anterior deltoids (front shoulders), but it also engages the lateral deltoids (side shoulders), core muscles, and trapezius (upper back).
comments.Weight Selection: This is an exercise where it is easy to pick a weight that is too heavy. Rather err on the lighter side, and strive for a strict form where you focus on getting good contact with your delts.
comments.Progression: You can increase the weight of the plate, the duration of the hold, or the number of sets and reps as you get stronger.
comments.Variations: You can also perform this exercise with dumbbells or kettlebells instead of a weight plate.

alternativesAndVariations.Front Raise: Involves lifting the weight with straight arms in front of you, targeting the front deltoids. The main difference is that the front raise is a dynamic exercise, while the front hold is an isometric exercise.
alternativesAndVariations.Lateral Raise: Focuses on the lateral deltoids, lifting the weight out to the sides with a slight bend in the elbows. It targets different parts of the shoulder muscles.
alternativesAndVariations.Arnold Press: A compound exercise that works the front, side, and rear deltoids, involving a rotating movement as you press the weights overhead.
alternativesAndVariations.Overhead Press: A compound exercise that works the shoulders, triceps, and upper back, pressing the weight overhead from a standing or seated position.

front-hold.tempo: N/A - The front hold is an isometric exercise, meaning there is no movement involved. Therefore, tempo doesn't apply to this exercise.
